CABINET 56 (35).Meeting of the Cabinet to be held at No. 10, downing street, S.W. 1, on WEDNESDAY , 18th DECEMBER, 1935,at 11.0 a.m.AGENDA.1. THE ITALO-ABYSSINIAN DISPUTE.(Reference Cabinet 55 (35)).2. EGYPT: REINPORCEMENT OP THE GARRISON. -(Reference Cabinet 54 (35) , Conclusion 4).Note by the Secretary, covering extracts from minutes of the Sub-Committee on Defence Policyand Requirements.(C.P* 23^ (35) - circulated herewith).3. ATLANTIC AIR ROUTE - (if required).(Reference Cabinet 51 (35) , Conclusion 5).4* PROCEEDINGS OP THE INTERNATIONAL LABOUR OPFICE INRELATION TO PROPOSALS PGR A 40 HOUR WORKING WEEK.(Reference Cabinet 30 (35), Conclusion 8).Memorandum by the Minister of Labour.(CP. 239 (35) - already circulated).5. PROPOSALS BEFORE THE INTERNATIONAL LABOUR OFFICE ONTHE SUBJECT OF HOLIDAYS WITH PAY.Memorandum by the Minister of Labour.(CP. 240 (35) - already circulated.6. GOVERNMENT BUILDINGS IN WHITEHALL GARDENS,(Reference Cabinet 51 (35) , Conclusion 9).Memorandum by the First Commissioner of vi/orks.(CP. 229 (35) - already circulated).. v-.-..r""-T^CTJhvrts DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)2 C RET. COPY NO._ 12th Conclusions (35) of Home Affairs Committee - tohe circulated..(i) Air Navigation,Bill.(Reference Cabinet 51 (55) , Conclusion 6).Memorandum by the Secretary of State forAir;, covering draft Bill.(H.A. 33 (35) - already circulated).(ii) Unemployment Insurance (Agriculture) Bill.(Reference Cabinet 51 (35) j, Conclusion 8).Memorandum by the Minister of Labour,covering draft Bill.(H.A. 34 (35) - already circulated).(iii) Land Registration Bill.(Reference Cabinet 51 (35)Conclusion 4).Memorandum by the Lord Chancellor,covering draft Bill.(H.A. 37 (35) - already circulated).(iv) Petroleum (Transfer of Licences) Bill.(Reference Cabinet 5 (35)^ Conclusion 9).Memorandum by the Home Secretary,covering draft Bill.(h.A. 32 (35) - already circulated).(v) Coinage Offences Bill.(Reference Cabinet 51 (35), Conclusion 4).Memorandum by the Home Secretary,covering draft Bill.(K.A. 36 (35) - already circulated).(vi) Sugar Industry (Re-organization) Bill.,(Reference Cabinet 40 (35), Conclusion 7).Memorandum by the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries, covering draft Bill.(H.A. 38 (35) - already circulated).(vii) Crown Lands Bill.(Reference Cabinet 51 (35) Conclusion 9).Memorandum by the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries;, covering draft Bill.(H.A. 35 (35) - already circulated).(Si signed) M. P. A. HANKEY ,Secretary to the Cabinet.'2, Whitehall Gardens , S."W. 1,16th December, 1935. (THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY1S GOVERNMENT. )SECRET.COPY NO.CABINET 56 (35).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet heldat 10, Downing Street, S.W.1., on WEDNESDAY,18th DECEMBER, 1935, at 11 a.m.PRESENT:The Right Hon. Stanley Baldwin, M.P. ,Prime Minister. (in the Chair.)The Right Hon.J. Ramsay.MacDonald,Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon.The Viscount Hailsham,Lord Chancellor.The Right Hon.Neville Chamberlain, M.P. ,Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon.Sir John Simon, G. C. S. I. ,K.C.V.O. , 0. B. E. , K. C. , M.P.,Secretary of State for HomeAffairs.The Right Hon.The Viscount Halifax, K,G, ,G. C. S. I. , G. C. I. E. ,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon.Malcolm MacDonald,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs.The Most Hon.The Marquess of Zetland,G.C.S. I. , G. C. I.E. , Secretaryof state for India,The Right Hon.J.H* Thomas, M. P. ,Secretary of State for theColonies.The Right Hon.The Viscount Monsell, G. B. E. ,First Lord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon.Walter Elliot, M. C. ? M. P. ,Minister for Agriculture andFisheries.The Right Hon.Sir Kingsley Wood, M,P. ,Minister of Health.The Right Hon.A. Duff cooper, D. S. 0. , M,P.Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon.The Viscount Swinton, G. B. E.M.C. , Secretary of Statefor Air.The Right Hon.Sir Godfrey Collins, K. B. E.,CM. G. , M. P. , Secretary ofState for Scotland.The Right Hon.Walter Runciman, M,P.,president of the Board ofTrade.The Right Hon.Lerd Eustace Percy, M.P.,Minister without pertfolio.The Right Hon.Oliver Stanley, M. C. , M, P. ,president of the Board ofEducation.The Right Hon.Ernest Brown, M. C. , M.P. ,Minister of Labour,The Right Hon. ,W. Ormsby-Gore, M.P, ,First Commissioner of Works.Colonel Sir M. P. A. Hankey. G, C B. , G.C.M.G. , G. C. V. 0. , ..... Secretary THE ITALO-abyssinian dispute.suggestion to amend theI opposition motion.(previous reference:.Cabinet 55 (35)Conclusion 3).1. At the outset of the meeting the cabinet discussed the drafting of a suitable amendment to be put forward in reply to the Opposition motion in the House of Commons. It was felt, however,that it would be premature to attempt to draft it until later in the day when further information from Geneva and elsewhere would be available.The Cabinet agreed:That the Prime Minister, the Chancellorof the Exchequer, the Home secretary and the Parliamentary Secretary tothe Treasury should meet later in theday to consider the drafting of an amendment.-1- THE ITALO-ABYS3INIAN-DISPUTE.iThe Forth-coming-parliamentary debate.(previous reference:Cabinet 55 (35)Conclusion 3).I (362. The Cabinet discussed generally and in detail the handling in Parliament of the difficult situation arising out of the Anglo-French proposed peace terms.The Chancellor of the Exchequer, who had seen the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (whowas still indisposed) gave the Cabinet a resume of what he understood to be the general line that theForeign Secretary intended to take in the forthcoming debate.The matter was discussed at some length, andat the request of the Prime Minister, the Chancellorof the Exchequer undertook to see the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs and inform him of the viewsof the Cabinet. 5. The Cabinet had before them the following conclusions of the Sab-Committee on Defence Policyand Requirements (CP.-232 (35)) circulated to theCabinet by direction of the Prime Minister, on thesubject of the Defence of Egypt:-At their Fourteenth Meeting held onNovember 2 5th:-(l(c)(ii)) To authorise the ,Var Officeto despatch to Egypt as soonas possible the mobile forcesconsidered necessary for thedefence against Italian attack from Libya, i.e.,One Light ^ank Battalion,One Company Medium Tanks,One Mechanised. Field ArtilleryBrigade,Armoured Car Unit, and ancillary Troops .At their Sixteenth Meeting, held onDecember 12th:-(a) To authorise the .?ar Office to makethe necessary arrangements to despatch from Rome reinforcements of the strengthof one Infantry Brigade to Egypt, assoon as practicable .(b) To authorise the tfar Office to askfor volunteers from the reserve inorder to bring up to strength+h certain administrative personnel needed forthis reinforce or cement" .iThe Prime Minister said he had received a communication from the Foreign Secretary expressing the hope that the Cabinet would approve the despatchof the proposed reinforcements to Egypt.The Cabinet agreed:To approve the despatch of there reinforcements recommended by theSub-Committee on Defence Policyand Requirements as set forth above. THIS ATLANTICAIR ROUTE.(previous reference:I&binet 51 (35)Conclusion 5).FA4. The Secretary of State for Air reported thatas the result of the Cabinet decision referred toin the margin, representatives of the United Kingdomand of the Dominions had co-operated effectively in negotiations with the Government of the UnitedStates of America at Washington on the subject ofthe Atlantic Air Route. He had not yet obtainedfull details, but he could report that they had arrived at a reasonably good agreement. He wasnot quite sure whether the reciprocity had been asgood as he had hoped, but he thought the positionso far as the Atlantic Air Route was concerned was satisfactory. He had exercised caution in refusinge.g.concessions/at Hong Kong until he had receivedfurther details. INTERNET TONALLABOUR ORGAN-ISA"" TON.Proposal? fora Porty-T-TourIfeek.(previous reference:Cabinet SO(3*), Con-clusion 8.)5. The Cabinet had. before the,- a Memorandum bythe Minister of Labour (C.P.-239 (35)) on the subjec4of the proceedings of the International Labour Organ-isation in relation to the proposals for a Forty-HourWorking Week. Questionnaires had. been received, from geneva relating to public works undertaken orsubsidised by Governments' building and civil engineering; iron and steel wo^ks ' an-1 coal mining.The primary question relating to each field ofindustry was in the following form:"Do you consider it desirable that theInternational Labour Conference should,adopt, in the form of a. Draft Convention,int er nat io na 1 re gul a tions f o r t hereduction of hours of work in accordancewith the principle laid down in theForty-Hour Week Convention, 1935?"The short answer to the above question, in the view^ the Minister o" Labour, should, be in the negative.Special points arose in regard to public worksundertaken or subsidised by Governments, and coalmining. As to the former the Minister suggestedthat it would be wrong, to legislate in the matter of hours not on the basis of the nature of an activity,but according to whether or not the activity was directly or indirectly being conducted under Govern-ment auspices. With respect to the latter theMinister did not propose to reply to the questionnaireat present, but attached to his Memorandum a draft.reply to the 40-hour week proposals in relation to building and Civil Engineering, and. Iron and SteelWorks, for the.approval of his colleagues.The Cabinet agreed:To approve the policy proposed by theMinister of Labour set forth in CP. 239 (35),as well as his proposed draft reply to theForty-Hour Week proposals in relation to building and civil engineering and ironand steel works. internationallabour organ-isa^ ton ."Holidaysv? ith Pay" .(previous reference erene e:Cabinet 31(35), Con-clusion 5.)6, The Cabinet had before the..:- a Memorandum bythe Minister of Labour (CP.-240 (35)) relating to proposals before the International Labour organisation on the subject of Holidays with Pay. He thought itwould be impossible, for reasons set forth in hisMe ;o rand urn, to support a proposal for a DraftConvention which would indicate the possibility oflegislation Nevertheless it appeared undesirable toadopt a purely negative attitude towards the extensionof holidays with pay. He therefore suggested, thatHis Majesty's Government should support a proposalfor a Recoinmendat ion which would not imply an obligation to pass legislation, and. attached forthe consideration of his colleagues a draft replyto be sent to the International Labour Organisation.The Minister of Labour reported that he now wished to make an addition to the draft reply(see below).The Minister of Labour, in connection withthe various matters that had to be considered as mentioned in paragraph 7 of CP. 240 (35), undertook to examine and bear in mind the question of standards of efficiency.The Cabinet agreed:To approve the following draft reply(in which the new words are underlined)to be sent to the International LabourOrganisation:His Majesty's Government are ofopinion that holidays with pay should beprovided wherever circumstances permit.They feel, however, that apart from other difficulties attendant upon an attemptto deal with this matteriby means iofinternational regulations the considera-tion which has so far been given to theproblem has not taken into account thegreat problem presented by the largeproportion of workpeople who during theyear work for different employers or whoare not continuously employed. It does not appear, therefore, that it would be possible to adopt international regu-lations in the form of a Draft Convention.His Majesty's Government, however, wouldbe prepared to support the adoption of a recommendation which would have the objectof encouraging all practicable steps to betaxcen to extend the provision of holidays with pay and of stimulatingfurther consideration of this subject. roVTiRNMHN" 7. The Cabinet had before them a Memo rand um byrjILDlNGS IK , uJjjjrp^LL. the First Commissioner of works ' CP.-229 (35)) inform-ing them of developments that had. taken place in the(previous reference: matter of the proposed new Government Buildings infiabiriet 51, Con- Whitehall, and. asking approval to proceed forthwithelusion 9 .)with the preparation of working drawings and otherpreliminaries an'" to make such provision as might berequire'' to meet the cost of the acquisition of the site and of building operations in the Estimates forthe ensuing financial year.Plans, designs and models of the proposed new buildings were exhibited in a corner of the cabinet room.The First Commissioner of works supplementedverbally the information contained in his Memorandum.A number of difficulties had had to be surmounted.The first had been to get agreement to the site;then to get the architect's plans adopted. Thefirst proposal for a "spinal" plan had been rejected by the Fine Arts Commission. Then the architecthad been thrown back on a plan for three internalcourts. His original design had been altered very considerably, and the present design reflected anagreement reached between the architect and the FineArts Commission. The London County Council had approved the scheme in principle. Their BuildingCommittee had approved the elevation, layoutand design, and probably the formal approval of theCouncil would soon be received. The Westminster city council had also approved. The Air Ministry's lease ingingsway expired at the end of 1939. Consequently,a beginning ought to be made with the demolition of thenorth end of Whitehall Gardens early in 1936 in order that the buildings to accommodate the Air Ministryat that end might he completed by the date proposed.The Minister recalled that there had been represen-tations by the Civil Service that some of thearrangements weve very bad especially in privatehouses that had been converted into offices.The Air Ministry, who now only had 85 square feetfor each member of the clerical staff, would in thenew building, have 97 square feet compared with theAdmiralty's 98 square feet which was the best in theCivil Service. He added that he was encounteringincreasing difficulty in obtaining accommodation for .official purposes anywhere within the Whitehall area.The case, therefore, for developing the new site wasvery strong. The matter of finance was one for theChancellor of the Exchequer. 'Some criticisms were made of the designs.The Chancellor of the Exchequer regretted that he had not yet had time to deal with thefinancial aspects of the question.The Cabinet agreed:To approve the proposals of the first commissioner of Works as set forth in cp. 229 (55), subject to leaving tothe Chancellor of the Exchequer thefinancial aspects of the matter. the airNAVIGATIONbill.previous reference:Cabinet 51 (35)Conclusion 6).&'i^c^ $lc^no thai" I8. The Cabinet had under consideration aMemorandum by the Secretary of State for Air(H.A. 33 (35)) covering the draft Air NavigationBill, which covereda variety of matters on which legislation was required owing to the greatdevelopments in aviation during the last fifteen years; together with the following recommendation by the Committee of Home Affairs (H.i:i..C. 12th Conclus-ions (35), Minute l):To authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of Commons of the air navigation Bill in the form of the draft annexed to H.it. 33 (35), subject to agreement being reached between thePresident of the Board of Trade and theSecretary of State for Air in regard to part III of the Bill, and subject alsoto any drafting or other minor alterations that may be found necessary or desirable.The Secretary of State for Air informed theCabinet that he and the President of the Board ofTrade had reached a satisfactory agreement in regardto Part III of the Bill under which the Board of trade would appoint a Committee^^on^he=^n=s=u'r^^&^^f^e=e4^s.*this.icmftauUd/The President of the Board of Trade confirmed the Cabinet agreed:To authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of Commons of the air navigation Bill in the form of the draft annexed to H.A. 33 (35) , subject to any drafting or other minor alterations that may be found necessary or desirable. 9* The Cabinet had under consideration aMemorandum by the Minister of Labour (H.A. 34 (35))covering the draft Unemployment Insurance(agriculture) Bill which followed in the mainthe recommendations on the subject of the Unemploy-ment Insurance Statutory Committee. TheConclusions reached by the Committee of HomeAffairs (H.a.C. 12th Conclusions (35), Minute 2)were as follows:(l) To draw the special attention of theCabinet to the matters summarised in(a), (b), (c) and (d) of the aboveMinute;(2) To request the Minister of Labour and parliamentary Counsel to consider thetransfer of the provisions in clause 3(4)relating to the 30/- maximum to someless consx^icuous part of the clause;(3) To recommend the Cabinet to authorise theimmediate introduction in the House ofCommons of the Unemployment Insurance(Agriculture) Bill in the form of thedraft annexed to H,A. 34 (35), subjectto (l) and (2) above and subject alsoto any drafting or other minor altera-tions that may be found necessary or desirable.The Cabinet gave general approval to theproposals of the Minister of Labour as setout in H.A. 34 (35), subject to the followingprovisos:-(i) There should be provision in the Billfor a maximum limit of 30/- to the weekly rate of benefit, but that before the Bill is taken in Committeethe Ministers concerned should considerthe question whether, in addition toenabling the Unemployment insurance statutory Committee to recommend achange in the limit, the Minister ofLabour should also take power to vary the limit by Regulations;(ii) The initial qualifying payment ofcontributions should be as in the draftBill attached to H.A. 34 (35) on theunderstanding that it might be necessaryto amend the clause in Committee so asto remove the time limit of two years; (iii) The provision relating to reducedcontributions for long hiringsshould remain as in the draft bill attached to H.A. 34 (35) on theunderstanding that the question ofthe method by which the reduction is to be made effective (i*e. whetherthe regulations contemplated inthe Bill should -provide that thereduction should be made by wayof refund, or should leave it opento the Minister to adopt some otherprocedure) should be discussed bythe Ministers concerned before theBill is considered in committee with a view to introducing any necessary amendment at that stage.Subject to the foregoing the Cabinet approved the recommendation of the Committee of HomeAffairs as set out in (3) above. THE LAND 10, Cabinet had under consideration a Memo- '* " 3REGISTRATIONETLL. randum by the Lord Chancellor (tT,A,-37 (3^)) covering the draft Land Registration Bill, the object of which(previous reference: was to carry out the recommendations of two DepartmentalCabinet ^1, Con- Committees; namely, the Land Transfer Committeeelusion 4.)(Cmd.4775) of 1935, and the Dormant Funds Committee(Cmd.41^2) of 1932: together with the following recommendation of the Committee of Nome affairs thereon IH.A .C, 12th Conclusions (3C), Minute 3):-"To authorise the immediate introduction in the House of Commons of the LandRegistration Bill in the form of thedraft annexed to -T.A.-37 (3r0, subjectto any drafting or other minor altera-tions that may be found necessary or desirable ."The Cabinet approved the above recommendation of the Committeeof Nome Affairs, rptrg pwTROLETTM 11. The Cabinet ha.^ under consideration a .(TRANSFER of licences) FILL. Joint Memorandum hy the T-Tome Secretary and theSecretary of State for Scotland. (H.A.-32 (35))(previous reference: covering the draft Petroleum (Transfer of Licences)Cabinet 2^(3^), Con- Bill, the object of which was to amend the Petroleumelusion 9 .)(Consolidation) Act 1928, in order to legalise thetransfer of licences for the storage of petroleumspirit: together with the following recommendationof the Committee of Rome Affairs thereon (H.A.C. 12thConclusions (35), Minute 4):-,!,T1o authorise the introduction forthwith in the Ho us e of Commons of the Petroleum-Transfer of Licences) Bill in the formof the draft annexed to TJ.A.-32 (35),subject to any drafting or other minor'alterations that might be found neces-sary or desirable."The Cabinet approved the recommendationof the Committee of Home Affairs asset forth above. THE COINAGE 12. Trie Cabinet had under consideration a Memo-OFRENCES BILL.randu:.- by the Nome Secretary fT-!.A.-36 (35)) covering(Previous the draft Coinage Offences Bill, which was drafted to reference:Cabinet 51 consolidate the Coinage Offences Acts, 1851 and 1935,(35), Con-clusion 4.) and the Counterfeit Medal Act, 1883: together withthe following recommendation of the Committee of-Tome Affairs thereon (H.A ,C . 12th Conclusions (35),minute e 5) : -1,rno authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of Lords of the CoinageOffences Bill in the form of the draft annexed, to H.A.-36 (35), subject toany drafting or other minor alterations that might be found necessary or *esir-able."The Cabinet approved the recommendationof the Committee of Home Affairs asset forth above. THE SUGAR 13. The Cabinet had under consideration aINDUSTRY(REORGANIZATION) Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture andBILL.Fisheries (H.A. 38 (35)), covering the draft(previous reference:Cabinet 40 (35)Conclusion 7).Sugar Industry (Re-organization) Bill which was designed to carry out the policy announced in astatement made by the Minister in the House ofCommons on the 30th July, 1955; together with thefollowing recommendation of the Committee ofHome Affairs thereon (H.A.G. 12th Conclusions (35),Minute 6):To authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of Commons of the sugar industry (Re-organization) Bill in theform of the draft annexed to H*A. 38 (35),subject:(a) to Cabinet approval of the principleof Clause 15, dealing with schemesas to the licensing of registeredrefiners;(b) to the Chancellor of the Exchequer,the President of the Board of Tradeand the Secretary of State forScotland being satisfied as to thefinal form of the Bill;(c) to any other minor or drafting amend-ments that may be found necessary or desirable.*/ith reference to (-fe*) above-, the Presidentof the Board of Trade stated that he had had someconve rsation with the Chancellor of the Exchequer.He hoped that there would be no extension of theija-t&o-Bill;, though he admitted that he saw noI In his view the Bill/wasobjectionable but inevitable.The Cabinet agreed:To authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of Commons of the Sugar-16- Industry (Rc-organization) Billin the form of the draft annexed to H,A. 38 (35), subject to anyminor or drafting alterations thatmay be found necessary or desirable. so"HE CROWN 14. "he Cabinet had under consideration aLANDS BILL.Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture and(Previous Fisheries (H.A..-35 (35)) covering the draft- CrownReference:Cabinet 51 Lands Bill. "he Memorandum stated that before(35), Con-clusion 9.) certain Government building operations on the siteso^ Montagu T-Touse anci Richmond Terrace could be began,it -icul'1 be necessary that the rights of the westminster City Council and the Crown Estate PavingCommissioners in those sites should be extinguishe'1 ."his was provided for in the draft Bill, which wasalso designed to regularise certain transfers of themanagement of portions of Regent's park from tieCommissioners o^ Crown Lands to the Coimnis^ionersof Works, and also included a number of minor amendments of the Crown Lands Acts, "he recommenda-tion of the Committee of Home Affairs thereon(t-T,a.C. 12th Conclusions (3R) , Minute 7), was asfollows:-"To authorise the introduction forthwith in the T-OU3e of Commons of the crown lands Bill in the for.^ of the draft annexed, to '-t,a,-3r (3^), subject toany drafting or other minor altera-tions that night be found necessary or desirable ."The Cabinet approved the recommendationof the Committee of Home Affairs asset forth above. PARLIAMENTARY 15. The Prime Minister informed, hisARRANGEMENTS.colleagues that it was proposed that ParliamentDate of should meet on February 4th, 1936.Meeting. A 9 Os o &THE ITALO-abyssinian dispute.The SuggestedAbyssinianPort.("previous reference:Cabinet 55 (35)Conclusion 2).16* Just before the adjournment of the cabinet a question was asked as to what was the positionas to the difficulty in connection with theproposed Abyssinian corridor and port on the red sea after the Prime Minister's interview with theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs.The Prime Minister informed the Cabinetthat the following telegram had been sent to theBritish Minister at Addis Ababa on the 17thDecember:Please cancel last paragraph, inregard to Abyssinian railway construction in zone to be cededto give access to the sea, whichmay give rise to misunderstanding,as it does not accurately reproducethe substance of the discussions in Paris, Pull explanationfollows.In addition, a telegram had been sent to HisMajesty's Ambassador in Paris instructing him to clear up the position with the French Government,2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.I.,18th December, 1935,
The envelope with its contents formerly placed atthis point in the volume was removed for examination by the Cabinet Office in August 1967 , and is nowto be found under the following reference :Cab.23/90B
